div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria weekly as under for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with the Orient Railways Express Service for VIENNA, BERLIN, PARIS & LONDON.
The S. S. Osmanieh will resume her express sailings on May 8.

PALESTINE - SYRIA MAIL SERVICE.–The fast steamers Prince Abbas and Assouan leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caiffa (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Mersina, continuing in alternate weeks to Larnaca (Cyprus).

SUDAN DIRECT MAIL SERVICE.–The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express serice to Khartoum.
RED SEA COASTING MAIL SERVICE.–Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai), Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden
For further information refer to Co.'s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, Suez, or to THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd., HAMBURG-AMERIKA REISE-BUREAU or other Tourist Agencies.

div.head: The State of Egypt
div.p: "Though we are most anxious not to take up an unnecessarily alarmist attitude in regard to as a Egypt" says the "Spectator", "we feel obliged to return to the subject treated by us some three weeks ago. Evidence which we cannot doubt convinces us that serious harm is being done to the cause of good government in Egvpt—in other words, to the best interests of the Egyptian people—by the foolish and ill-considered agitation which is being conducted by a certain suction of British Radicals. The fact that those responsible for this agitation are well meaning and do not realize the consequences of their acts, does not in the least mitigate the evil that is being done. Mr. J. M. Robertson and his friends in England imagine that he is championing a popular cause and standing up for the rights of the people. In reality he is in danger of allowing himself to be made the cat's-paw of a combination of selfish and unscrupulous men whoso object is not popular rights or sound administration, but simply and solely to got rid of tho good government established by the British people through the instrumentality of Lord Cromer and his subordinates, and to substitute for it what we a have no hesitation in saying would prove the worst and most immoral form of despotism that the world can show-that is, not the crude despotism of primitive Mohamedanism, but of the Oriental who, while losing his own faith and principles, has gained nothing but evil from his intercourse with the West.

No one who knows anything of the facts can doubt that the most ruinous type of ruler, morally and economically, inflicted upon a Turkish province is tho Pasha who, with-a veneer of European civilization, has retained the instincts of primitive savagery. If the sophistries of Mr. Robertson and his friends prevail, and if for enlightened British rule it exists in Egypt today is substituted some ridiculous travesty of Parliamentary government, it is absolutely certain that tho result will not be merely a defective and blundering system of democracy, such as can no doubt be tolerated, and ought to be tolerated, while a people naturally fit for government are learning to use their freedom, but the most degraded form of Oriental despotism. The people of Egypt, we admit, do not appreciate fully the blessings of English rule, and yearn, no doubt, for the happy-go-lucky ways of the former regime. But this discontent with what they regard as the irksome tidiness and method of European administration is not enough to make them fit for true self government. Such self government they would find far more irksome than British rule. In order to avoid it they would, till the revolution point of misery had been reached, tolerate a return even to the squalid horrors of the Ismail regime. And unfortunately for Egypt, it is doubtful whether the revolution point would be reached before the country had been completely ruined for by nature the Egyptians are the most timid and submissive of men. Serious insurrection in Egypt against any power, however oppressive is almost unthinkable. It is true that the revolt of Arabi took place; but that was only because Arabi and his soldiers were unpaid. Had they received their pay, the Egyptian people would never have moved, nor would Arabi have come forward as a patriot. But though the Egyptian is absolutely submissive in the face of tyranny, he is a quick-witted man, and has a positive genius for intrigue. If you can assure him the strong arm of the law will not be invoked to crush conspiracy, and if he also is inspired with the notion, first, that his existing governors are likely to be worried into abounding the task of governing, and secondly, that when this is accomplished the sovereign authority will fall into the hands of another set of men whom he has a natural and traditional dread-that is, the old Pasha or Turkish class-he will be quick to throw himself at the feet of those who he imagines are destined to rule lower him in the future, and who he believes it will be to his interest to conciliate. That is what is beginning to happen now. The Egyptian people, though they love platitude and sophistry for their own sakes, and to a certain extent enjoy the rhetoric of discontent, are probably at heart not very much impressed by the talk about liberty and free government with which their native newspaper are now flooded,-partly under the inspiration of British doctrinaires. They judge from such talk, however, that for some reason or other the British people have got tired of ruling them, and are going to give up the task, and that thereupon sovereignty with all its privileges and powers will return into the hands of Khedive and his entourage. Accordingly there is a tidal wave of frothy anti-British and pro-Khedival sentiment spreading throughout the Nile Valley, and making its impression felt even in the distant Sudan, where the Army and the minor civilian employees of the Government are being made uneasy by the news that there is not be some great though unexplained alteration in the political situation. That they could not describe in detail what the change is to be is quite immaterial. The Oriental's first impulse when he fears change is to take out an insurance policy against that change by currying favour with those whom he thinks are likely in the end to get the upper hand. There is an Egyptian proverb which declares that when one meets "the bear in the day of his wrath the wise man feeds him with honey, while the fool emits him on teahead with a pole." The bear in his what used to stand for the British power, and hence that bear was largely fed with honey. Now, thanks to the notion that Mr. Robertson and his friends control the British Government, and are going to put an end to Lord Cromer's authority, the Khedive and his friends, decked out with some phrases about Parliamentary institutions, are the bear which is to be cajoled and propitiated.

We have so often of late had occasion to criticize the action of the present Government that we must take care not to let it be supposed that we are suggesting that either his Majesty's Ministers or the Liberal Party as a whole are responsible for the very grave situation which has arisen in Egypt. We are quite confident that not only Sir Edward Grey, but the Prime Minister and the rest of his colleagues are prefect sound in regard to Egypt and have not the slightest intention of withdrawing their support from Lord Cromer. Unfortunately however, the knowledge of this fact possessed by the British people is not shared by the Egyptians. They have been taught to believe that the present Government is entirely in the hands of men like Mr. Robertson, and that the strange and mysterious body, the House of Commons, has entirely altered its views at to how Egypt is to be ruled. In these circumstances, it is most welcome to find a Liberal Member of Parliament like Sir Christopher Furness making strong protest against the attempts of Mr. Roberson and those who think with him to ruin the splendid work which we have accomplished in Egypt during the last twenty years.

div.p: According to "Al Mokattam," the appointments of Dr Graham Beylis Director and Mr. Gamer as Sub-Director of the Public Health Department will be discussed by the Council of Ministers at its next meeting .

div.head: Sudan Inscription
div.p: Some Berlin savants are now studying a series of old Nubian papyri, written partly Merolitic and partly in other known characters. The results of their labours are expected to throw a good deal of light upon the hitherto undecipherable inscriptions in the Sudan.

div.head: Coal Import
div.p: Between January 1 and April 4, 315,964 tons of coal were imported into Egypt, which 156,886 tons were Welsh, 64,104 New castle, 58,799 Yorkshire, 13,779 Scotch, and 20,396 other qualities. During the corresponding period of last year the coal imports totalled 322.845 tons.

div.head: Tewfik Palace Hotel
div.p: The Tewflk Palace Hotel at Helouan having been sold to an English firm in Cairo will, by the terms of the registered contract of sale, be given over to the purchasers on the 14th of May next Dr. A.J.M. Bentley, in consequence, will retire from the position of medical director, which he has held there for many years, and from the day of transfer take up his residence in Cairo.

div.head: British Recreation Club
div.p: A concert will be held in the British Recreation Club, Cairo, on Saturday evening next, commencing at 9 o'clock The following ladies and gentlemen have kindly consented to contribute to the program-Lady Vaida Machell, Madame Amster, Mrs, Nolan (Harp), Mrs. Elliot Smith (Violin), Mrs. Wilding (Piano), Lieut.-Col. Donegan, R.A M C., Mr.W. Hayes, Capt. A. N Tucker, R.E., Mr. S. H. Trimen. The concert is reserved for members of the club, to whom tickets will shortly be sent.

div.head: A Forthcoming Consert
div.p: A concert will be held in the hall of the Union Aristique, 4 Rue Rosette, on -Monday next by Mr. Nicolas Dillon, the well-known Russian violinist, who will be assisted by MM. E. Papasian (piano) and A. Romeo (violincello) Mr. Nicolas Dillon is an admirable and clever violinist, with a most sympathetic touch and perfect execution, as the habitues of the New Khedival Hotel this season well know, and we hope that on this occasion, wh ch will be one of the last on which he will appear, he will a large and appreciative audience as he deserves

div.head: Pappa's Grocery Storos
div.p: On Saturday evening at 6 o'clock Mr Nicola Pappa, whose name and grocery stores are so well-known in Alexandria inaugurated the new premises which he has taken in Rue Cherif Pacha, at the corner of Rue Antoniadis, by extending unlimited hospitality to all who cared to be his guests on this occasion. Needless to say these were numerous and champgane flowed freely. Indeed, we cannot do better than wish Mr. Pappa as many customers daily as he had guests on Saturday evening. Mr. Pappa's new premises are exceedingly well furnished and generally fitted up, and as for his goods, both wet and dry, they need no commendation for they are well-known to all Alexandrians.

div.head: Departure For Port-Said
div.p: At a quarter to ten this morning H.R.H the Duke of Connaught, accompanied be Lewa Watson Pasha and escorted by a detachment of innskilling Dragoons, drove to Abdeen Palace to bid farewell to H.H. the Khedive. On his return to the British Agency the Duke and Duchess of Connaught and Princess Patricia Patricia, accompanied by Lord and Lady Cromer proceeded direct to the station, where they were met by a guard of honour, of the 3rd Battalion Colstream Guards. Shortly before eleven o'clock H.H. the Khedive appeared to wish the Royal party good-bye and punctually at 11 am the special train left the station for Port-Said, where their Royal Highnesses will embark this afternoon on the P. and SS. Caledonia

div.head: Zizinia Theater
div.p: Since times change and we with them, the caricature or even a ludicrously faithful pre-sentiment of what is out of date is rather a clue and catchpenny form of pathos. Sochat least was the impression left us by "Brichanteaui" a long play adapted by M de Feraudy himself from M- Jales Claretie's novel of that name- Brichanteau is an actor of the old llorid and hymbasitic school, relegated first to the provinces and then to oblivion by the more reposeful theatre which is at present in vogue. We have no read the novel but make no doubt that M. Clrette attains his primary object in engagine our sympathy with the vicissitudes of the sueperannuated old actor; he is intended, we are sure, to earn our pity in his obstinate self-confidence dogs him quixotically during the greater part of his existence, rather than to hold up to our ridicule his old-fashioned ranting absurdities. But as a play, M de Feraudy had satirized that of some famous modern actor, his own for instance. In Robertson's David Garrick, '' Sir Charles Wydnham would easily love our sympathy if he had to go through some long delcamatory speech in the style of the period, Mr. Pinero in "Trewlawnt of the Wells," also recognised the danger and keeps his Mr. and Mrs.Telfer well in the background, and what dismal failures the "Crummleses" and "Miss Petowker" would be if we had to take them seriously! Thus it is that when we have once made Brichanteau's acquiantance and perceive the error of his ways, we gradually begin to lose interest in him. His necessarily consistent antiquity begins to pall.

Nous avous change tout cela and the laborious process of the change does not as we have said enlist our sympathy. The first act, incomparably the best of the four, is rather on the lines of "A Pantomime Rehersal" and it is hard to say which is the more amusing of the two. Not only "was M. de Feraudy's performance on Friday last as great a mascrpiece as any of his former triumphs, but his make-up and the general atmosphere created wero no small delight. He was very well assisted in this and following act by Mille Hel ne Mais and M. Goornae. Acts II and III, which would be the hotter for some cuts, simply show us various and more or less detached incidents in Brichmiteau's meteoric career: his idea of theatrical honour, theatrical love, licit and illicit, theatrical duelling and so forth which if they do not precisely entrance our enthusiasm for the plot, leave us nevertheless amazed once more at M. de Feraudy's powerful dramatic gifts. In Act II M. Houry's Englishman had a very favourable and deserved reception. The last act does not compare very favourably with "Cyrano de Bergerac" though the resemblance is marked by the hero's dying in harness with a final confession of love. Here M. de Feraudy, admirable to the last, was well supported by Mile Van Doren. On the whole we were disappointed that Feraudy the playwrite, did not come within measurable distance of Feraudy the actor.

After smiliug condescendingly on Brichaneteau's old-fashioned attitundinarising, we had to reverse our train of thought and admit the conquest of the "hohero Tochtcr" and her scientific education by the homely back-to-the- is land marry-and-live happily-ever-after doctrine set forth in M Brieux's "Blanchette." given on Saturday evening. The play, an up-to-date version of the prodigal son, is not one of M. a Brieux's best, but nevertheless his usual searchlight is brought to bear on modern social problems, and he thus fulfils one of the most importain aims of true dramas. The weak point is the finale, which, with guilty haste, descends into the fallacies of Brichanteauism. Apart from this, the adherence to realism is maintained simply and effectively. Onco more M. de Feraudy, as Roussct, drew a life-like portrait. To be uniformally successful night after night in roles whose variety is as striking as their execution is faithful is a proof of talent such as few modern actors can present. We think after this outburst, we need only add, that those few misguided players who have not yet visited the 'Zizinia" are to be sincerely pitied.

As "Blanchette" Mlle Van Doren kept well within the limit of her powers and infused her adruous part with sufficient force and sympathy to worthily second M de Feraudy. Mme Marie Laure as Mme Roussct was again good in her quiet way; but she should display more embarrassment in the last act where she is concealing her daughter's presence from her Mme Rousset is not the stage lady of fashion who can perpetrate all sorts of enomouities without turning a hair.

div.head: Port Said Strike
CONCESSIONS TO CANAL LABOURERS
OUTLOK MORE SERIOUS
div.p: FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT

Since Friday there has been no change in the state of affairs as regard the possibilities of a settlement, with the exception that the Canal Company's men have returned to work with an increase of P T.l per day, but as these men were not in any way connected with the discharging and bunkering Arabs on strike, it cannot to be assumed that the latter will be granted their demands. Attempts were made on Friday night to prevent any men going to the harbour to work. The strikers had sent out a number of armed pickets to guard all roads leading from the Arab village to the harbour, bat but with the exception of a little interference, nothing happened of a sensational character. The men who are working such as the Salt Works and Cabal Company labourers are escorted by a squad of police to and from the harbour. Owing to the disturbance which occurred during the coaling of the Orient Mail steamer Ormuz, every effort is being made by port police to prevent the strikers from congregating around the harbour, whilst the town police are also kept busy in the European quarter. The extra draft of police from Cairo together with officers have arrived and are rendering great service to a local force

Although there is apparently a dead-lock in the negotiations, the masters again met in counsel at 9.30 this morning. The meeting was not of long duration and althought Press representatives were not admitted, we understand little more was done than to report on the progress of discharging etc. The outlook is becoming more serious every day; cargoes of coal are arriving daily for the port, but, as the discharging has to be done by the ships own crews, the work is very slow, on an average about 200 tons being the daily output, whereas under ordinary circumstances about 800 tons is only considered a fair day's work. Many of these ships have other charters and owing to this strike, the likelihood is that in many cases these charters will have to be cancelled. This will mean a heavy loss to the shipowners; and the delays in bunkering steamers is also serious. Vessels taking 200 tons are frequently here twenty four hours.

div.head: THE GRANDMOULIN AFFAIR
WILL THERE BE LIBEL ACTIONS
div.p: One of the most interesting questions of the day in, Cairo is what action will M. Grandmoulin take in reference to the disgraceful charges that have been brought against him by the Nationalist Press. The English organ of Mustapha Pasha Kamel, the "Egyptian Standard" used the words "guilty, as he is of assassination" "in regards to the accidental shooting of the native boy by the French official of the Egyptian Government Under such circumstances it is obvious that M Grandmoulin has only one course open to him, namely to submit the question to the law courts. Everybody in this country sympathises with M. Grandmoulin owing to the atrocious charges brought against him and it is to be hoped that he will obtain some solatium. As, however, he is in official in the service of the Egyptian Government his line of action is dependent on his superiors and it is openly declared in native circles that the Nationalist Party is so powerful at the present time that it is believed that no action will be taken in this matter.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive, who spent yesterday at Koubbeh, drove this morning to Abdeen Palace where the Council of Ministers was held under his Highness's presidency. At 11 a.m. the Khedive drove to the station to say good­bye to T.R.H; the Duke and Duchess of Connaught and Princess Patricia.
This evening the Khedive will arrive at Alexandria where he will remain six days, which he will spend at Moritazah and Mariout.

The area of the property is 4650 square metres and the price paid was I.E 1/2 per metre. The workshops are situated at the end of the Boulac Road and in close proximity to the new bridge which is to connect that district with Ghezireh.

div.head: CAIRO'S DRAINAGE
THE LATENT THEORIES
div.p: The most serious problem awaiting solution in Cairo is the question of the new schemes for settling the difficulties of the drainage once and for all. The enormous growth of the city within the last few years has rendered a speedy solution of this grave problem absolutely inevitable and from every point of view the sanitation of the Capital of Egypt must be considered as among the most serious questions, with which Egypt will have to deal at once. There are at the present time about four projects for the consideration of the Ministry of Public Works. The specialist in this matter on whose decision so much depends, is Mr. Carkett James, the well-known Anglo-Indian drainage expert, who made the drainage of Bombay one of the most admirable in the East. He is strongly in favour of utilising the immediate neighbourhood of Tourah. This site is advantageous because there is an inlet into the Eastern hills, which will provide all the necessary area. At the present time this is only a bare expanse of desert, which is absolutely useless, except for a rifle range, which it is used by the British Rifle Club at Cairo, who could easily find a site for their exploits between that point and the city.

Another scheme is to make the sewage farm in the neighbourhood of Khanka, beyond Materieh and Marg. There is a large area of desert laud available. The objection to this site appears to lie in the fact that it is to the North East of the City and is farther away in point of distance than Tourah. Any other scheme, such as Rod-el-Farag will not be accepted, as the levels there are low and the water must naturally percolate into the Nile

div.head: NEW BRITISH CONSULATE
div.p: Mr. Adairi of H.M. Office of Works, arrives tomorrow from England to superinterad the erection of the new British Consulate in Cairo, which is to be built in tho RueGamih. El Cherkass near the Savoy Hotel and opposite the Austro-Hungarian Consulate General. The work of excavating and laying the foundations is now being proceeded with by Messrs. Sabatelli, the contractors, and it is expected that the building will be completed and ready for occupation in 10 or 12 months time, probably by next December. The area of the ground is a little 600 square metres and it was purchased in 1903 at the rate of P.T. 420 per metre whereas hand in the vicinity is now fetching from LE. 30 to LE 40. The total cost of the premises and site is estimated at about £10,000, for which amount a special grant was made by the British Government. The offices of the Consulate and the Consular Court will be on the ground floor, whilst the two upper storeys will as serve a residence for the Consul.

div.head: GREEK INDEPENDENCE DAY
div.p: The anniversary of the declaration of Greek Independence on the 7 April, 1821, was celebrated by the Greek colonies throughout Egypt yesterday with great enthusiasm. At Alexandria the day began with a special service at, the Evangelismo's Cathedral, which was conducted by the Patriarch, the Bishop of Tripoli and a large number of notables staff of clergy. The Consul General and a large number of notables attended. A reception followed at the Greek Consulate, the band of the Greek Philharmonic Society meanwhile playing before the Consulate. In the afternoon at 4 o'clock about ten thousand "people assembled at Chatby to assist at the laying of the foundation stone of Mr. Emanuel Benachi's orphanage. The ceremony took place under the patronage of the Patriarch, who conducted a religious service there. The Governor of Alexandria, representing the Khedive, M Scotidis, Dr. Schiess Paslia, Chataway Bey, Mr. and Mrs Benachi, Mr. Sinadino, Mr. George Zervndachi, Messrs M and S. Salvago, Mr. Georgin, headmaster of the Greek School and the professional Staff and pupils, Mrs. Stampa, headmistress of the Greek Girls School with the Stuff and pupils and a large crowd of people. The stone was blessed by the Patriarch and laid by Benachi, assisted by the chiefs of the Greek gymnasium, Messrs. L. Risopoulos; A. Skenderanis, Alex. Maori. L. Laksrdis, and young Michel Salvago.

The stone was christened by a big bottle of champagne. After the ceremony four eloquent speeches were delivered by Messrs. M Sinadino, E. Benachi, Scotidis, and the Patriarch. The guests then resorted to the buffet. The two Greek bands of the Greek Philharmonic Society and the schools played during the proceedings.

div.head: THE YEMEN TROUBLE.
TURKS SUFFER HEAVY LOSSES. (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT.) Aden, April 3
div.p: Advices received from the Yemen state that several encounters have taken place at Dhodan, Afrika and 'Al-Wadi,.small Turkish districts in Humdan, between the Turks and the raiding commanders of the Imam. The Turks lost about 600. killed and wounded, and the Arabs about 300. ^ •

Al Mikdad, one of the mobile commanders of the Imam, I reported to have made his way to 'Ans, a Turkish district about three day's march from Sana, with the .intention of cutting off communications between Ans from Sana. Al Mikdad, who is said to be deformed, has been for some years past a thron in the side of the Turks. He was formerly, in Turkish service; but owing to some disputes about land in which the Turks decided for his relatives, he rebelled and has since given, them a lot of trouble by frequent raids He has hitherto led a freebooting life. Mohamed Ali Paslia, is reported to have commited suicide at Sana.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL GEOGRAPHICAL SOCIETY
div.p: A most successful meeting of the Khedivial Geographical Society was held on Saturday afternoon in the hall of the Legislative Council, then the diploma d'honneur was conferred upon the Duke of the Abbruzia, the explorer of the Ruwenzori, it being recieved on behalf of his Highness by the Italian Minister. H.H. Khedive was represented by Ahmed Bey Chefik, and the Government by Mustapha Pasha Fahmi and Saad Pacha Zagloul. Among there present were Prince Fouad, several high Governemnt officials, Egyptian and European notables, and many ladies. A plan of Ruwenzori drawn by M. Pelogrin, a large picture of the mountain drawn by M. Trivella, and a collection of photographs taken by M. Sella served to illustrate the addresses given by Abbate Pasha and Dr. Schweinfurth. At the close the President handed the diploma to the Italian Minister. The diploma is a magnificent work of art by M. Pollaroli, professor of art at he Italian schools.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The S.S. Belgian Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Malta on Saturday and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Wednesday next.
The S.S. Persion Prince, with passengers and general cargo left Malta yesterday for Alexandria, via Misrate, and is due to arrive here on Friday next.
The Moss liner Seti sailed last Saturday for Liverpool via Malta and Algiers, with passengers, mails and general cargo, including 2,345 bales cotton.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL CAIRO.
div.p: Family Hotel. Built in 1904. Between Shepheard's Hotel and the Railway Station. Electric Light. Lift.
Sanitary arrangements up to-date. Open all the year round. Special terms for Government officials and Army of Occupation

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord Cromer's remark in his Report that "in the course of the short peripd during which, possibly, I may still be connected with Egyptian affairs" is the first allusion in his Reports to his approaching departure from Egypt
Lord and Lady Carnarvon, who have been staying at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, left for England on Saturday by the S. S. Oceana
Lord and Lady Meath left Alexandria this morning for Port-Said, where they will embark for home, this afternoon on the P.and O. S.S. Caledonia

Great sympathy has been aroused in Alexandrian society at the news of the death of the Countess de Vanreal, whuch took place yesterday, in, Paris. The Countess was the daughter of Mr. Eugene Debourg, the managing director of the Egyptian Salt and Soda Company Limited. His daughter married a few year's ago the Comte de Vaureal, a member of the old French nobility. She was confined a short time ago and afterwards was attacked by influenza, the malady leading to a fatal issue owing to her weak state of health. The Countess spent her youth in Alexandria and was a very popular figure in society here. Great sympathy is felt for M and Mme Eugene Debourg at their untimely loss.

Celebrating as it were his long and successful service in the Egyptian Postal Department, Saba Pasha issued invitations with a very liberal hand to a gymkhamuheld in the grounds of his residence at Bulkeley yesterday afternoon, and those who took tile advantage of being present had cause congratualte themselves for the favour. The combination of prettily decorated grounds, a well-arranged programme of nineteen events, an orchestra, the liberal provision of tea and refreshments, and an enthusiastic company of guests, made altogether a most enjoyable afternoon.

Mrs. Hogg wishes to say how deeply she has appreciated all the kind inquiries, all the beautiful gifts of flowers, and all the true sympathy and help, she has recieved. As she gets stronger she hopes to be able to answer personally all the kind letters she has had
Three months' leave of absence has been granted to Major W Bromilow, 1st Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers, and to Captain P. Lane, 3rd Battalion Colstream Guards

A large dinner party was given in the magnifiicent new restaurant of the Savoy Hotel Cairo on Friday night by Colonel and Mrs. Paterson whose guests included Count and Countess de Serionne, Judge and Mrs Tuck, Mr. Mrs. and the Misses de Villebois, Countess della Sala, Sir Horace and Lady Pinching, Judge and Mrs. Royle, Mr. and Mrs Comfort, Mr. and Mrs. Carton de Wiart, Mr. and Miss Farnale, Mr. and Mrs Spong, Mrs. and Miss Leverich, Mr. Iddings, Mrs. Iddiings, Mr. Carter Wilson, Baron Oppenheim, Mr. Maclean, Marquis de Fiorvanti, Mr. Whitworth Jones, Mrs. Alston, and Baron Herring, Colonel and Lady Granville Smith also entertained a large party, including, Lady Hilda Keith Falcon, Mr. and Mrs. Murray, Major and Mrs. Blunt, Major and Mrs. Hall, Mr. and Mrs. Phillips, Major and Mrs. Herbert, Mr. Fuller Maitland, Mr. Ward Aldam,Mr. Henry Rentinck.

WITHDRAWN FOR THE SESSION

div.p: The "Times" learns from Dublin that the government has abandoned the idea of introducing an Irish University Bill during the present session, believing that the Devolution Bill will occupy much time

Mr. Birrell denies that the University Bill has been withdrawn. He says that the Government's determination to deal with it at the earliest possible date is unaltered. Nevertheless, it is generally believed that pressure of work will not allow the passage of the Bill this session.

div.head:
MONETARY CORNER IN AMERICA.
PROSPECTS IMPROVING

div.p: The "Times" in its money article says that this week's purchases of gold by the banks confirm that the monetary corner in America has turned although the position our the Continent still requires watching. The brokers anticipate an early reduction in the bank rate.

div.head:
MCGILL UNIVERSITY ON FIRE
ENGINEERING BUILDING DESTROYED

div.p: The splendidly equipped engineering bilding of McGill University has been completely destroyed by fire. the loss amounts to 150,000

The French and German Legations in Morocco have arrived at a friendly arrangement regarding the difficult question of wireless telegraphy. The agreement is regarded as highly satisfactory from an international stand point.

div.head:
RUSSIAN MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS
JEWS FEAR OUTRAGES

QUEEN ALEXANDRIA JOINS KING EDWARD
KIING EDWARD INSPECTS JENA.

div.p: Queen Alexandra has arrived. King Edward inspected the Iena in the forenoon. their Majesties will sail for Carthagena in the evening.

Queen Alexandra has rejoined King Edward. The latter visited the Iena and said that he wished to make a personal testimony of his sympathy to the victims. Their Majesties, warmly acclaimed have left for Carthagena
After the departure of the King and Queen a storm sprang up along the coast. Several fishing baots were lost and other casulaties occurred. Four fishermen were drowned.

div.head:
FRENCH STEAMSHIP REGULATIONS
GENERAL STRIKE THREATENED

div.p: Telegrams recieved from the principal ports announced that the meetings of registered steamship services decided upon a general strike if Parliament votes the Governments project conceiving them without modification
The royal yacht Trinacria, conveying the King and Signor Tittoni on a visit to the King of Greece, has left Taranto for Piracus, escorted by warships
A commision consisting of two Generals and two Ulemas has left for Yemen with the object of negotiating a friendly settlement with the tribes
A gigantic food tratles strick is being organized here. The date is a secret. The Governemnt is prepared to take strong repressive measure
The French are laying down water pipes and construcing roads in the vicinity of ujda. Moorish artillerymen have recieved pay for the first time for eight months

The King and several Ministers have started for Carthagena. Owing to the Queen's condition they deferred their departure until the last moment. They will return immediately after the interview with King Edward
The bakers strike intended
The Dowager Empress of Russia has arrived
It is denied that Cardinal Merry del Val has resigned on account of the publication of Mgr Montaginini's papers

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLBUB
div.p: APRIL SKYE MEETING

Favored with excellent weather the first race meeting held at Alexandria this year attracted a fair and fashionable attendance on Saturday afternoon, and the sport was on the whole interestng. Although only five runners went to the pest for the Nile Plate a very close finish was witnessed. The face for the Regimental Cup, owners up, and the maiden Horse Plate produced food fields and teh keenly fought contests on teh post in each case caused a good deal of excitement. Between teh third and fourth race an auction was held, when the following horses the property of Major Gillson, were sold. Bidding was sold, but starting at LE 100 John Peel bap, whose engagements include the Club Stakes, Grand Prize of Alexandria, Great Annual Handicap and Summer Handicap, was knocked down for LE 180 Casino gab, advancing from LE 50 by LE bids, fetched LE 67 and Mutmir LE 35 Aeolus did not come under the hammer. The Bad of the 1st Royal Dublin Fusiliers conducted by Bandmaster A. Fawcette contributed as excellent programme of music, which greatly added to the enjoyment of the afternoon

KSC
POLO
OPEN CUP FINAL

T R H the Duke and Duchesses of Connaught and the Earl and Countess of Cromer honoured the Khedival Sporting Club with their presence on Saturday to witness the final of the Open Cup polo Competition and a very large number of Cairio residents were also present.
The final match was between the Staff and Departnental and the Inniskilling Dragoons and proved most interesting and exciting in fact the best match we have seen this season

The Staff and Departments were the favourites but the Dragoons played up wonderfully and outstayed their opponents: Major Haif for the winners and Capt Dunbar for the Staff were most conspicuous Capt Dunbar bringing off one most brilliant shots at goal. Mr. Jenkinson t back for hte Staff was very steady and sure. Messrs. Bowen and Holland played a surprinsgly good game, and Major Paterson as usual was in despensable to his side, always working hard and scoring off several difficult shorts
FIRST CHUKKER- Fast and keen, Mr. Holland scoring first point for teh Dragoons. After some excellent play by both sides the Staff equalized from a brilliant shot by Capt Dunbar
SECOND CHUKKER-Staff aded another, but the Guards pressed hard and were unfortunate in their shots at goal. Score. Staff 2. Dragoons 1.

THIRD CHUKKER-The Dragoons headway in this chukker, Major Paterson making a good shot under his pony and a good goal by Major Haig shortly afterwards gave the Dragoons the lead. Score Staff. 2, Dragoons 3.
FOURTH CHUKKER-The staff had little the best of the chukker, and scored 2 goals
Capt Bartlett putting in some clever work. Major Haig then scored another goal for his side. Score 4 goals all.
FIFTH CHUKKER- The Staff added another point and at the beginning of the last chukker had apparently won the game Score Staff 5 Dragoons 4

SIXTH CHUKKER- The Dragoons played up with great spirit, Major Haig palying a great game himself and at the same time kept his team going hard. The Dragoons scored 3 goals during this chukker in quick succession, Mr. Jenkinson made a brillaint goal the alst minute of the game but the Staff were beaten by one goal
FINAL SCORE
Staff and Departents, 6 goals Inniskilling Dragoons 7 goals

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.
